Sri Lanka are second in the one-day rankings and have lost only once in 18 matches. Those are statistics enough for England to be wary of Friday's Rose Bowl decider that will determine which of them reaches the Champions Trophy semi-final.

But there is another side to Sri Lanka, a side who struggle to adjust to English conditions, especially if there is drizzle on a nasty wind. This was the team on show in an awkward four-wicket win, with 37 balls to spare, against a Zimbabwe who England, not at their best, had already exposed as ingénues.

There were fleeting moments when one wondered if Zimbabwe might nick it. The Champions Trophy is finally warming up - not boiling point perhaps, but at least the temperature of a doorstep pint on a hot summer's morning.

If Sri Lanka struggled on the Oval's flatlands, even flatlands slightly spiced by drizzle, then they are unlikely to prosper at the Rose Bowl, where the bounce is variable. Yet this remains a Sri Lanka that can be inspired by one uppercut from Sanath Jayasuriya or one inswinger from Chaminda Vaas.

"It wasn't our prettiest win," admitted the captain Marvan Atapattu. "It takes time to adjust but we have got such a small amount of time. We need more application."

Sri Lanka had designs on beating Zimbabwe quickly enough to pass England on net run rate - so ensuring they reach the semi-final if their head-to-head is washed out. Even when Zimbabwe had transformed 85 for six into 191, Sri Lanka's task of winning within 27.5 overs was not impossible. But at 10 for two they decided just to win it.

From tomorrow the group stages conclude with Australia v New Zealand, England v Sri Lanka, South Africa v West Indies and India v Pakistan. That is more than good fortune for a tournament that needs all the good fortune it can get, it is creative planning. The seedings were based on ODI rankings - but the date when those rankings were assessed was shrewdly chosen.

When Zimbabwe were six down for 85, outdone by slick catching, yesterday's game felt like another mismatch. Even the gaggle of Sri Lankan spectators seemed leftovers from series past, right down to the man shivering in a T-shirt promoting the London "chicken 'n ribs" restaurant that caused such a furore when it illegally sponsored Arjuna Ranatunga's bat back in '97.

But Zimbabwe batted defiantly when the cause seemed lost. Elton Chigumbura's build creates the delusion that he is among the most senior of their new breed. In fact he is only 18, but he extended the good impression created against England with a pugnacious half-century and three wickets.

These Zimbabweans deserve a nod of respect. They might be the representatives of a deceitful board which has engineered a dispute of racist undertones with its white players. They might also be accused of legitimising Robert Mugabe's malevolent, tyrannical regime. But in cricketing terms they are guileless young men who have been thrust into the international arena and who have shown impressive spirit in adversity. Do not deny them that.

At this week's TUC, I have experienced deja vu and an odd sense of dislocation. Despite the flatness of Blair's speech and its tepid reception, most headlines reflect the trade union-government relationship as it ever was: the big guns battling, men in suits squaring up to each other. So far, so familiar. But is it?

Beneath the muted seaside wrangle over honouring the Warwick warranty and the direction of the next Labour government, something much more interesting is happening within the union and the wider labour movement. Over the past few decades, both party and unions have been revolutionised by the involvement of women in politics.

For New Labour, this has resulted in a generation of mid-ranking women in parliament and government, politicised by feminism and then by their experience of power, pressing on a wide range of issues relating to women's lives. For the trade unions, the change has more of the flavour of an emergency. With the dwindling of its traditional membership - put crudely, full-time men in manufacturing - has come a potentially vast new membership: part-time women working in the service sector.

Different kinds of workers, very different patterns of employment. But workers needing protection and representation all the same. Even this week, trade union leaders talk of this sea-change uncertainly, seeing in it something between a crisis and an opportunity. The result of these seismic shifts is a new agenda that keeps moving towards political centre stage; a substantive list of policy demands that has yet to be matched by a shift in political style - at leadership level, at least. High on the list is the campaign against the culture of long hours.

Since trade unionism began, cutting working time has been its priority. In the modern era of global capital, large corporations have encouraged flexible working as a way of keeping the new supply of women workers happy in their part-time, low-status jobs. But the call for a fair and flexible working life, geared more to family life, has a genuine urgency now. There's a generation of younger workers - men and women - who don't want their lives shredded by the demands of employment.

Equal pay has also taken a suprising hike up the political agenda. As the GMB's Kevin Curran argued this week, the gender pay gap is a "huge issue" for many of his members, a change reflected in Blair's July announcement of a new equal pay commission.

Add to these issues the potent new significance of childcare; campaigns for greater economic support for families in their early years; the politics of pensions; continuing campaigns on domestic violence and child protection. All this amounts to a new dimension in mainstream political life - one with real popular backing. But the question is: where is the reflection of all this at the highest level of labour politics? The answer is not straightforward. It's more a question of now you see it, now you don't.

Scan the TUC timetable for this week, and many of these issues are honourably present. Skip forward to the Labour party conference later this month, and one of the first fringe meetings will ask: has Labour delivered for women? There will be talk aplenty about gender. But all this excitement and effort has yet to be translated into a genuine shift in style, substance and spending.

Government, party and unions are stuffed with good sorts, men aged from 30 to 60 who can talk the hind leg off a donkey about work-life balance or the unfairness of pension arrangements on women, or the crucial place of childcare in the modern economy. Long ago, Tony Blair was considered one of these. Gordon Brown in his remote way is still considered a friend of feminism. Alan Milburn's decision to choose family over political career put him firmly among the gender modernisers; even now, he is still talked about as a keen advocate of equality.

But if gender issues are no longer dismissed out of hand, they are still treated as second rank. Like Milburn and his family, it's as if the "soft" stuff is important until something else, like real political power, comes along. But soft may just be the new hard. Or it should be. Fairer pay, fairer pensions, more investment in the early years; truly domestic issues may well be the way to the electorate's reluctant heart, as Blair acknowledged.

Earlier this year, Polly Toynbee made a strong case for building a third-term manifesto around the idea of a children's centre in every constituency; the political focus of a new constellation of values. So far, there's no sign of the political will or the real money to do so. But perhaps this is not surprising, coming from a government that has made so little public noise about some of its substantive achievements on the eradication of child poverty.

It's all rather a pity and a waste, given that support for New Labour is declining among the 35- to 54-year-old age group. Among its natural constituency - younger women and working-class women - there's a reluctance to come out and vote. For them, New Labour still means business as usual. The trade unions face a similar demographic crisis. They too need to make more of issues that matter to the new workforce; not just on pay and time, but what Kevin Curran rather graphically describes as "a very, very biased view of women at work at every level".

There have been heroic efforts to reach out and meet the concerns of the new constituencies, but the top of the unions, like that of government, remains safely in the hands of fiftysomething men. Government and unions have more in common than they think: they face a common crisis in terms of their natural supporters.

The next few years offer them a chance to show those supporters, and the public, that they - like the nation and the economy - have been transformed by women's greater participation in public life; and that political structures and priorities have kept pace with that monumental change. The failure to do so could signal the death knell of labour, old and new.

Jonathan Freedland argues that the prime minister is "a man who has run out of ideas" (Tony Blair's survival is an affront to our constitution, September 11).

The struggle in the Labour party is not about Tony Blair's lack of ideas. It is down to a refusal by many in the party to accept them. The one big idea for Labour was espousing "the enterprise of the market and the rigour of competition", written down as a new core principle in clause four. Yet when policy makers argue in favour of relying on such forces, many of the party faithful cry foul.

There are lots more examples of the new vision: fairness but no favours for the unions; accepting the global economy as a reality; politics of the centre and so on.

Now Freedland argues that "every day [Blair] remains [as leader] is an affront to the constitution". Yet his argument only concerns the opinions of people in the party. Blair was chosen by the electorate, on a set of principles and policies presented in clear terms. To seek to remove the prime minister now would be a far greater affront to our constitution.
Mike Allott
Eastleigh, Hants

Such is the glory of the unwritten British constitution that Blair can quite legitimately believe the only way he can be turfed out of Downing Street is by allowing Michael Howard in. Any other exit strategy would be an affront to the man's pride and vanity.

Jonathan Freedland, a great admirer of so many things American, must look longingly across the Atlantic at the 22nd amendment of the US constitution, which states: "No person shall be elected to the office of the president more than twice." If that sensible guard against dictatorship was the case here, who would not be celebrating as the clock ticked down on Blair's premiership?
Rick Bryant
Exeter, Devon

Jonathan Freedland rightly exposes the constitutional cracks that have enabled our prime minister to evade accountability for the war in Iraq. An impotent opposition in parliament, a subservient judiciary, a useless church, a cowardly media and a cynical Labour party have allowed this country to go to war not just on one lie, but a lot of lies. I am amazed that people are not taking to the streets in outrage at this shabby and shameful misgovernment.

But there's one more plank of the constitution that Freedland didn't mention: we, the people. An election is not the answer: we might want to vote Labour, but we don't want to vote for this prime minister. The only way left is to take to the streets and demonstrate and to do it soon. Remember the WI?
Gillian Gunner
Sherborne, Dorset

At last a senior journalist is showing his mettle. Freedland's article, like most of his comments, reminds me of the old fearless Guardian of liberal values. Britain is approaching a totalitarian state by consent. In such a state there is no oppression, no political prisoners and no visible dissent. Every citizen and every institution is in a zombified acquiescence, morally ambivalent, intellectually philistine and thoroughly mean.

Orpington, Kent

It is Jonathan Freedland's elitism, not Tony Blair's premiership, that is "an affront to our constitution". He dislikes Blair, and so do the "mandarins", "the establishment including the judiciary", and "the press". Freedland's argument is clear. Leave politics to the elite, because you can't trust the people.
